docs.abstract: What parents see when they look at their children differs from what researchers -- or strangers -- might find.
docs.lead_paragraph: About a year ago at this time I ran a post titled "How Well Do You Know Your Children." It was specifically about parents' perceptions of their children's nutrition and exercise habits (those with preschoolers reported that their children ate healthy food and exercised regularly, and those with middle-school children reported that theirs did not) and how often our perceptions are wrong (when examined more closely, there was very little difference in eating and exercise between the two age groups.) More broadly, my post raised the question of how regularly there is "a mismatch between what we see when we look at our children, and what is really there."
docs.snippet: What parents see when they look at their children differs from what researchers -- or strangers -- might find.

headline.seo: A Doctor’s Mammogram Mission Turns Personal
headline.print_headline: A Doctor’s Mammogram Mission Turns Personal

docs.lead_paragraph: There are lingering, uncomfortable questions about how to balance the benefits of early diagnosis of breast cancer with the harms of mammography.

docs.abstract: Older people with the highest levels of "good" HDL cholesterol were 60 percent less likely to develop Alzheimer's than those with the lowest HDL levels.
docs.lead_paragraph: Could HDL cholesterol -- the good kind linked to lower heart disease risk -- also protect people from dementia?

headline.seo: Save the Children Breaks With Soda Tax Effort
